
### AT&T versus Intel syntax 


* AT&amp;T syntax: <br /> `movq $42, 100(%rbx,%rcx,4)`
* Intel syntax: <br / > `mov QWORD PTR [rbx+rcx*4+100], 42`
* effect (pseudo-C): <br /> `memory[rbx + rcx * 4 + 100] <- 42`


### AT&T syntax (1) 


`movq $42, 100(%rbx,%rcx,4)`

* destination <em>last</em>
* constants start with <code>\$</code>
* registers start with <code>%</code>


### AT&T syntax (2) 


`movq $42, 100(%rbx,%rcx,4)`

* operand length: <code>q</code> 
   * <code>l</code> = 4; <code>w</code> = 2; <code>b</code> = 1
   * can be omitted when implied by context
* <code>100(%rbx,%rcx,4)</code>: <br> <code>memory[100 + rbx + rcx * 4]</code>
* <code>sub %rax, %rbx</code>: <code>rbx ‚Üê rbx - rax</code>


### Intel syntax

`mov QWORD PTR [RBX + RCX * 4 + 100], 42`

* destination <em>first</em>
* <code>[...]</code> indicates location in memory
* <code>QWORD PTR [...]</code> for 8 bytes in memory 

   * DWORD for 4
   * WORD for 2
   * BYTE for 1
   * can be omitted when implied by context
